issue.title: test_estimator or a variant should work with object (not classes)

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
For easy testing and debugging, it would be great if `test_estimator` or a variant thereof could be extended to work with object instances, not classes; alternatively, classes with default parameter settings not read from a file, but given as an argument.

This is for:
* making it easier for local (non-contributing) extenders to write their own tests
* making new estimators easier to debug, e.g., by making it easier to vary the parameters in the test
* to enable extension and manual testing without having to clone the repository (with a simple workflow that could be added to the tutorials)

body: I would like a mapping overview of all the testing that goes on in sktime, then work towards a simple guide to tests, where to put them, what to test for each module etc etc. Improving classifier testing (removing excluded etc) is a mid term goal for me, but its more likely to happen sooner if its easier and intuitive to do
Agreed - I've put a simple testing guide in the extension guidelines, at the end of the forecaster tutorial
And appveyor and azure build take ages (2-3 hours??), speeding up is indeed a great suggestion.

issue.title: estimator tests to allow objects, not just classes

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR addresses #1027 and part of #1032.
The post-PR state allows testing of concrete objects, not just classes, using the current test suite.

This is achieved by modifying the `estimator_checks._construct_instance` utility:

* pre-PR, this always assumes the argument `Estimator` is a class, and creates an object after lookup of default parameters from the default parameter registry, using those parameters. This object is then returned.
* post-PR, it first checks whether the argument is a class or an object. If an object, it just returns the argument; if a class, it proceeds as pre-PR.

Since `_construct_instance` is called at the start of every estimator related test, this change enables all those tests to take objects as well as classes.

For the user, this allows convenient command line testing of newly written estimators without first having to deposit default parameters in the default parameter registry, or changing the registry file to test with different parameter settings.

body:
I recently saw this video giving whirlwind tour of unittesting using UnitTests. 

[Ned Batchelder: Getting Started Testing - PyCon 2014 - YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FxSsnHeWQBY) 

My summary of main ideas, which might help:

* First chunk (~20 mins) is basics of unittests.
* Goes a tiny bit under-the-hood of UnitTests
* Big tip/opinion: treat unittesting the same way as you do rest of software engineering. should refactor it, should write helper functions, if appropriate should have tests for tests
* Idea of mock objects, to isolate what a test is testing, and to remove slow parts of tests (if appropriate). but big downside is that mock objects have to be manualyl updated if there are any interface changes
* use coverage tools to check which lines have/have not been tested
* things to read up on in your own time: dependency injection, ddt (data driven tests), jenkins and travis for continuous testing (I think this is for software in deployment?), integration tests, load testing

Been skimming through some of Ted Kaminski's essays on software engineering, and in this one https://www.tedinski.com/2018/05/01/designing-imperative-code-with-properties-in-mind.html they argue for 'property testing' and recommend the package [Hypothesis](https://hypothesis.readthedocs.io/en/latest/). From hypothesis homepage:

> Think of a normal unit test as being something like the following:
> * Set up some data.
> * Perform some operations on the data.
> * Assert something about the result.

> Hypothesis lets you write tests which instead look like this:
> * For all data matching some specification.
> * Perform some operations on the data.
> * Assert something about the result.

(Apologies - I realise I am not directly helping with the key steps given in the issue description, but this seems like best place to share knowledge about unittests)

issue.title: Good first issues & getting started, for new contributors

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

labels.name: interfacing algorithms
labels.description: Interfacing existing algorithms/estimators for other packages

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
A number of good issues to start working on as a new contributor.
Contributions to documentation are especially appreciated.

### getting started with contributions

1. Say hello [on Slack](https://join.slack.com/t/sktime-group/shared_invite/zt-62i7aejn-vXc3nOWF26S_P3VXFPWisQ) and get set up for development, see [instructions in the developer guide](https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/developer_guide.html)
2. Pick a “good first issue” to work on, see a collection [in this summary issue](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1147), or from [this list](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/labels/good%20first%20issue)
suggestion: pick something small with simple content to learn the “process”
3. Feel free to attend the regular community collab sessions or one of the topic specific stand-ups and tech sessions (see schedule on slack)
4. Once your first PR is merged and you’ve seen how things work, think about your regular time commitment. Optionally, continue attending the Friday community collaboration sessions and stand-ups; or, optionally, [apply for mentoring](https://github.com/sktime/mentoring/blob/main/README.md)

### introductory and user testing

* work through the [sktime tutorials](https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/tutorials.html) and record feedback, you can post it in this issue #1447
* work through user testing sheets for [forecasting](https://github.com/sktime/sktime-workshops/blob/main/sktime_worksheet_forecasting.ipynb) or [time series classification](https://github.com/sktime/sktime-workshops/blob/main/sktime_worksheet_TSC.ipynb), record feedback and send us your user testing sheet with code (e.g., attach to this issue)
* open an issue with a time series related algorithm that you would like to see implemented or interfaced in `sktime`
* work through the [installation instructions](https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/installation.html) to install a development version of `sktime`. Record carefully things that are unclear or don't work as described, return the full feedback to us (e.g., in an issue).

### contributors new to open source

* documentation: many code files are missing module and class/function docstrings. Pick a file and start adding these. A good starting point are estimator algorithms, these should follow the general documentation style outlined in #1148 or the [extension templates](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/tree/main/extension_templates). If you start, post the name of the estimator you are working on in #1148; when you open a PR, refer to the issue.
* documentation: many code files are missing examples. Pick a file and start adding these. a good starting point are estimator algorithms, and time series classifiers, see #932 and #1148

NOTE: #1148 and #932 are closed, but there are still modules without good docstrings. They are just no longer tracked by the issue, which covered the priority items only. So, feel free to go through the code base and help improve docstrings!

### small-to-medium documentation and technical writing tasks

* other smaller issues in the [documentation milestone](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/milestone/6)
* the [user guide](https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/user_guide.html) is incomplete. Help is appreciated - the best approach may be converting the [tutorials](https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/tutorials.html) in a well-written guide.
* the [tutorial for time series classification](https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/tutorials.html) should be re-factored, in the style of the forecasting tutorial
* extension templates for time series regression and time series annotation should be written. The current [extension templates](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/tree/main/extension_templates) can be used as an extension template template.

### small-to-medium python/coding tasks

* current open small tasks with a "recipe": https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3429
* pick an unverified bug from the bugfixing board: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/projects/18 and try to reproduce it. Post operating system, python version and (if relevant) package versions, and whether you can yes/no. Investigate further if the bug looks simple - but note that bugs can be anywhere between easy to very difficult to track down.
* Pick an algorithm to implement or interface, according to the [extension templates](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/tree/main/extension_templates). Possible choices are forecasters (univariate or multivariate), time series classifiers, time series regressors, annotators, distances, kernels - these can be existing feature requests, or new suggestions. We currently do not recommend transformers as they undergo refactoring.
* implement `get_fitted_params` functionality in estimators where this is missing (currently most of them). Related issue for composite estimators: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1497

### mid to longer term tasks

For contributing across a period of weeks or months, consider joining one of the major workstreams and weekly stand-ups on Fridays. Join the slack (see link in README) and say hello on the contributors channel.

Current workstreams, overview here https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/projects?type=classic:
* forecasting https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/projects/3 and https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/projects/25
* deep learning, benchmarking https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/projects/31
* time series annotation, segmentation, change points https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/projects/27
* pipelines, pywatts integration https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/projects/30
* docs, maintenance, testing https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/projects/26

### challenging tasks

✨ Your time to shine! ✨ 
Talk to a core dev before starting with these.
Also have a look at the roadmap #228

* deep learning interfaces and models, see workstream above
* `get_report` interface for model inspection #971
* refactor/redesign: forecasting interface for stream update/prediction #982
* help build/design new experimental module: distances/kernels
* help build/design new experimental module: annotations (segmentation, change point detection, outlier detection)
* help build/design new experimental module: sequence alignment

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Partly fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1032

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
* Adds GitHub Action CI scripts for Windows building and testing

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

issue.title: [ENH] in CI, test only lines that are changed by PR

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
I think it would be a great improvement if the PR tests only ran the tests that touch changed lines - it would solve our issue with testing taking hours for every PR.

I'm not sure how one would do this as part of the integrated tests, but there seem to be packages like `pytest-testmon` or `pytest-picked` that allow to do this in-principle.

Perhaps someone who has experience with this sees that it's just a few-line change somewhere and can pick this up?

issue.title: [ENH] Make unit tests for API compliance portable

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Related issues: #1032 #1505 https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/421

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I've sketched out a possible solution here: https://github.com/mloning/minimal-python-project-portable-pytest

Major changes:
* collect estimator tests in classes, one class for the `BaseEstimator` and one for each scitype 
* define test classes discoverable by pytest, inheriting from collection classes, possibly using multiple inheritance

Minor changes:
* add `configure_get_estimators` so that it can be easily reused/configured in companion packages 
* rename `all_estimators` to `get_estimators` for readability
* rename `estimator_instance` to `estimator_object` in line with common class/object distinction and avoiding ambiguity with "instance" as an i.i.d. data sample 

Notes:
* If we use multiple inheritance for the class that collects the tests, we need to make sure that the parent classes have unique method names to avoid overriding methods
* There still is a lot of duplication  in https://github.com/mloning/minimal-python-project-portable-pytest between the base package and companion package, especially regarding `configure_pytest_generate_tests`

body:
>Just to clarify. Do you want a fix for appveyor or is the idea to anyway move away from appveyor and use the CI of Github

Yes, @corvusrabus, to both.

There was the *urgent problem* to get windows CI/CD to run again by whatever means necessary (#1539), this would have been solved by either and/or removing C/cython requirements.

Mid-term, we want to move to GitHub actions consistently, see #1032 and @mloning's incomplete attempt in #1319.

@mloning I think has paused on this after a myriad of issues appeared, so more pair of eyes would be appreciated.

issue.title: [BUG] failing appveyor/windows builds

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Since a while, our Windows builds on appveyor are failing.
We don't precisely know yet what is causing this - the builds are failing before any `sktime` specific code is run.
@mloning has looked into this but it seems to be a time intensive issue to diagnose.

A possible solution is this PR https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/1319 which moves the windows builds to GitHub actions, but this fails with the C compiler issues, and it's unclear how to fix (except by random googling and seeing what works).

Help and pointers are very much appreciated - does not look straightforward.

Perhaps @freddyaboulton or @corvusrabus have an idea, given earlier help with CI/CD?
